title: Web Games vs Websites
overview: Rewire your mindset from event-driven UI to frame-driven simulation.
objectives: Understand the difference between event-driven and frame-driven architectures
Learn why DOM is not suitable for high-performance games
Grasp the concept of a real-time simulation

sections.title: Why Games Are Different
sections.content:
### What is a Server?
A server is defined by **behavior**, not hardware. It listens on a port, receives requests, and sends responses.

### Web Apps vs Games
**Web Apps** consist of event-driven UIs that react to user input and idle most of the time.

**Games** run continuous loops, updating state every frame and rendering constantly. A game is a **real-time simulation**.

sections.title: Core Differences
sections.content:
| Websites | Games |
|---|---|
| Event-based | Frame-based |
| Stateless UI | Stateful world |
| Low CPU usage | Continuous CPU/GPU usage |
| DOM-heavy | Canvas/WebGL |

questions.question: Why does `setInterval` often fail for games?
options: It does not sync with the screen refresh rate
questions.correctAnswer: It does not sync with the screen refresh rate
questions.explanation: setInterval creates janky movement because it ignores the monitor's VSync cycle. requestAnimationFrame is preferred.

questions.question: What drives a game's logic?
questions.explanation: Games update their state continuously every frame, regardless of user input.
